key_insight: Explicit, quantitative rubrics can be turned into reward signals to fine-tune LLMs so they produce research plans that better satisfy constraints and implicit quality requirements.
problem_solved: Language models often generate research plans that miss constraints, lack feasibility, or ignore implicit evaluation criteria; this work addresses how to train models to follow multi-criteria standards for usable scientific planning.
method: Design task-specific rubrics that decompose plan quality into measurable dimensions (e.g., feasibility, novelty, resource constraints, clarity).

Train reward models to predict rubric scores and use those rewards to fine-tune a base LLM (e.g., via reward-weighted fine-tuning / RL-style optimization) so outputs optimize for rubric-aligned quality.
Evaluate with automated rubric scoring plus human expert review and iterate on rubric definitions to close gaps between model behavior and researcher expectations.
impact: Rubric-based rewards make AI co-scientists produce more constraint-compliant, implementable plans, improving trust and usefulness for researchers and enabling broader application of LLMs to structured, safety-sensitive scientific tasks.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: Rubric definitions → Reward model → Fine-tuned LLM → Generated research plan (annotated feedback loop).
Before vs After examples: two short research plans side-by-side showing common failures (constraint violations) vs rubric-optimized output.
Bar chart or radar chart: average rubric-dimension scores for baseline vs rubric-trained model to show multidimensional improvement.
Icon set representing rubric criteria (feasibility, resources, novelty, clarity) with brief captions.
paper_title: Training AI Co-Scientists Using Rubric Rewards
paper_authors: Shashwat Goel, Rishi Hazra, Dulhan Jayalath, Timon Willi, Parag Jain
